papers.title: A whole-planet model of the Earth without life for terrestrial exoplanet studies
papers.abstract: As the only known habitable (and inhabited) planet in the universe, Earth informs our search for life elsewhere. Future telescopes like the Habitable Worlds Observatory (HWO) will soon look for life on rocky worlds around Sun-like stars, so it is critical that we understand how to distinguish habitable planets from inhabited planets. However, it remains unknown if life is necessary to maintain a habitable planet, or how all of the components of an evolving planet impact habitability over time. To address these open questions, we present a coupled interior-atmosphere evolution model of the Earth without life from 50 Myr to 5 Gyr that reproduces 19 key observations of the pre-industrial Earth within measurement uncertainties after 4.5 Gyr. We also produce a reflected light spectrum covering the possible wavelength range of HWO. Our findings support the view that life is not required to maintain habitable surface conditions. The model presented here is apt for predicting the long-term habitability of Earth-like exoplanets via evolving bulk properties. By generating realistic reflected light spectra from evolved atmospheric states, this model represents significant progress towards whole-planet modeling, which may ultimately provide a robust abiotic baseline for interpreting biosignature observations with HWO.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Scientists are on the verge of answering one of humanity's biggest questions: Are we alone in the universe? With powerful new telescopes like the upcoming Habitable Worlds Observatory, we'll soon be able to study Earth-like planets orbiting distant stars and search for signs of life. But here's the challenge: How do we tell the difference between a planet that could support life and one that actually does? This research tackles that fundamental puzzle by asking a fascinating "what if" question‚Äîwhat would our own Earth look like if life had never evolved here?

**What They Did**

Researchers created an incredibly detailed computer simulation of Earth without any living organisms, running it like a time-lapse movie from 50 million years after our planet formed all the way to 5 billion years in the future. Think of it as building a virtual Earth from the ground up, accounting for everything from volcanic activity and atmospheric chemistry to ocean cycles and rock weathering‚Äîbut with no plants, animals, or microbes in the mix. They then tested their lifeless Earth model against 19 real measurements from our actual planet before the Industrial Revolution, essentially checking whether their simulation matched the Earth we know.

**Key Findings**

The results were striking: their lifeless Earth model successfully reproduced nearly all the key features of our real planet, staying within the margin of error for scientific measurements. This suggests that life might not be necessary to keep a planet habitable‚Äîcontradicting what many scientists previously believed. The team also generated a simulated spectrum of light that would bounce off their lifeless Earth, mimicking what future telescopes would actually see when observing similar planets.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough gives astronomers a crucial reference point‚Äîa baseline for what a habitable but lifeless world looks like from space. When we start discovering potentially habitable exoplanets, we'll be able to compare them against this model to better identify which ones might actually harbor life, making our search for cosmic neighbors far more precise.

papers.title: Dynamical Interactions and Habitability in the TOI-700 Multi-Planet System
papers.abstract: The discovery of a second earth sized planet (TOI-700e) interior to the habitable candidate TOI-700d has prompted further research into this system, as the additional planet makes the TOI-700 system a tightly packed multi-planet system with multiple planets in the habitable zone, like TRAPPIST-1. In this work, we use the planetary evolution code VPLanet to assess the potential habitability of TOI-700d and TOI-700e. We first examine their orbital dynamics to evaluate the influence of planet-planet interactions on the planet spin, obliquity, and eccentricity. We then investigate whether these interactions are sufficient to cause either TOI-700d or e to be perturbed out of a habitable state, and whether we expect either planet could retain surface oceans over Gyr timescales. Together, these analyses allow us to assess the long-term habitability prospects of both TOI-700d and TOI-700e. We find that multi-planet interactions in the TOI-700 system do not prevent either planet from potentially retaining habitable conditions; however, we find that TOI-700e is located very near the boundary of the tidally locked habitable zone (arXiv:1705.10362), suggesting further work is needed to determine whether it is truly habitable.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine finding not just one, but two Earth-sized planets orbiting in the "Goldilocks zone" around a distant star‚Äîthat perfect region where temperatures are just right for liquid water to exist. That's exactly what astronomers have discovered in the TOI-700 system, located about 100 light-years from Earth. This rare find gives us a precious opportunity to study what happens when multiple potentially habitable worlds exist in the same solar system. Understanding these cosmic neighborhoods could help us answer one of humanity's biggest questions: how common are planets like Earth, and could they harbor life?

**What They Did**

The research team used a sophisticated computer program called VPLanet to run cosmic simulations of the TOI-700 system over billions of years. Think of it like a celestial video game that fast-forwards through time, showing how planets interact with each other through gravity. The scientists examined how these gravitational tugs-of-war might affect each planet's spin, tilt, and orbital path‚Äîall factors that influence climate and habitability. They also investigated whether these planetary interactions could knock either world out of the habitable zone or cause them to lose their atmospheres and oceans over cosmic time.

**Key Findings**

The good news is that both planets appear capable of maintaining habitable conditions despite their gravitational dance. The interactions between TOI-700d and TOI-700e aren't violent enough to destroy their chances of supporting liquid water. However, TOI-700e sits dangerously close to becoming "tidally locked"‚Äîmeaning one side would permanently face its star while the other remains frozen in eternal darkness, like our Moon does with Earth. This precarious position makes its habitability questionable.

**Looking Forward**

This research demonstrates that multi-planet systems in habitable zones might be more stable than previously thought, potentially doubling the number of worlds where life could emerge. The findings will guide future telescope observations and help astronomers prioritize which exoplanets deserve closer study in our ongoing search for life beyond Earth.

papers.title: What to make of the Earth's curiously intermediate land fraction?
papers.abstract: Approximately two-thirds of the Earth, the only known inhabited planet, is covered in ocean. Why not 0.01% or 99.99%? It has been previously suggested that this may represent a certain degree of fine-tuning, and thus perhaps observers are a-priori more likely to develop on those rare worlds with nearly equal land-ocean ratios, such as our own. In this work, we take the single datum of the Earth and then use Bayesian inference to compare four models for the probability distribution of a planet becoming inhabited by observers as a function of land-fraction, f, which we classify as i) land-centric ii) ocean-centric iii) equi-centric and iv) indifference. We find that no model is strongly favoured over the others, but that 1) the land-centric model is disfavoured over all others, and, 2) the equi-centric model is favoured over all competitors. Further, we show that more extreme models with heavy tail-weighting are strongly disfavoured even when conditioned upon the Earth alone. For example, a land-centric model where the median planet has f=0.82 (or greater) is in strong tension with our existence. Finally, we consider the potential addition of more data via Mars or exoplanets. Should paleo-Mars have once harboured life and had f<0.20, then this would strongly favour the ocean-centric model for life, over a land-centric hypothesis. We show that strong evidence for/against the equi-centric model versus its competitors would likely require at least a dozen inhabited exoplanets, offering a well-motivated sample size for future experiments.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Earth is a water world‚Äîabout two-thirds of our planet's surface is covered by oceans, with the remaining third being dry land. This might seem perfectly normal to us, but when you think about it, it's actually quite puzzling. Why isn't Earth almost entirely ocean, like a giant water balloon, or mostly land, like a desert planet? This question matters because understanding what makes a planet habitable could help us find life elsewhere in the universe. If there's something special about Earth's land-to-ocean ratio that makes complex life possible, then we'd know what to look for when hunting for aliens among the thousands of planets orbiting other stars.

**What They Did**

The researchers treated Earth as their only example of a planet with life (since it's the only one we know of so far) and used statistical methods to test four different theories about what makes a world habitable. Think of it like having only one winning lottery ticket and trying to figure out what made it special. They compared models where life prefers mostly land, mostly ocean, a balanced mix of both, or doesn't care about the ratio at all. Using a mathematical approach called Bayesian inference‚Äîessentially a sophisticated way of updating your beliefs when you get new information‚Äîthey calculated which theory best explains why we exist on a planet with Earth's particular land-ocean split.

**Key Findings**

The results were surprisingly nuanced. No single theory emerged as a clear winner, but some patterns did appear. The idea that life strongly prefers land-dominated worlds performed worst among all the options tested. Meanwhile, the theory suggesting life thrives best on planets with roughly equal amounts of land and ocean‚Äîlike Earth‚Äîcame out slightly ahead of the others. The researchers also found that extreme scenarios don't work well. For instance, if most habitable planets typically had 82% or more land coverage, it would be very unlikely that we'd end up on a world like Earth.

**Looking Forward**

This research provides a roadmap for testing these ideas as we discover more about life in our solar system and beyond. If scientists confirm that Mars once hosted life when it had more water and less land than Earth, that would strongly support the ocean-friendly theory. For planets around other stars, the researchers estimate we'd need to find about a dozen worlds with life before we could definitively determine which land-ocean recipe works best for habitability.

papers.title: Ocean Circulation on Tide-locked Lava Worlds: 3D Modeling with a Simple Boundary Iteration Method
papers.abstract: Tide-locked lava worlds are surface-melted rocky planets under 1:1 tidally locked orbit (i.e., synchronously rotating) with orbital period being equal to rotation period and with permanent hot dayside and cold nightside. Previous studies on this type of planets employed scaling analyses and two-dimensional (2D) simulations. This work is a continuation of the previous researches but including the effect of the Coriolis force and the simulation domain is extended to a 3D global sphere. We find that under the condition with thermal-only forcing (without surface wind stresses), the area-mean ocean depth is about 50--300 m (depending on vertical diffusivity) and the area-mean effect of horizontal ocean heat transport (in the order of 10¬≥ to 10‚Å¥ W m‚Åª¬≤) is significantly smaller than stellar radiation (in the order of 10‚Å∂ W m‚Åª¬≤ at the substellar region), being consistent with previous results. Different from 2D results, due to the effect of the Coriolis force, large-scale horizontal gyres form on the dayside, ocean currents near the west boundaries are much stronger than that near the east boundaries (called as ``western intensification''), the deepest ocean is not right at the substellar point but in the middle latitudes as the vertical diffusivity is moderate or large, and meanwhile there exists significant asymmetry between the west and the east of the substellar point. These results establish a first picture for the 3D thermal-driven ocean circulation and confirm that the lava ocean should be shallow on tide-locked lava worlds.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine a world where one side faces its star in eternal daylight while the other remains in perpetual darkness‚Äîand where the surface is so hot it melts into an ocean of lava. These aren't scenes from science fiction, but real planets called tide-locked lava worlds that orbit close to their stars. Understanding how molten rock flows across these extreme planets helps us grasp the incredible diversity of worlds beyond our solar system and reveals the fundamental physics governing planetary climates under the most extreme conditions imaginable.

**What They Did**

Scientists created the first comprehensive 3D computer model of how lava oceans would flow on these bizarre worlds. Think of it like creating a detailed weather simulation, but instead of tracking air and water, they're modeling currents of molten rock across an entire planet. Previous studies only looked at simplified 2D slices, like examining a map instead of a globe. This new research included the Coriolis effect‚Äîthe same force that causes hurricanes to spin on Earth‚Äîto see how planetary rotation affects lava flow patterns across the entire spherical surface.

**Key Findings**

The lava oceans are surprisingly shallow, averaging just 50 to 300 meters deep‚Äîabout the height of a skyscraper. Despite flowing at thousands of degrees, these molten currents are relatively weak compared to the intense stellar radiation, carrying roughly 1,000 times less heat than what the star delivers directly. The 3D modeling revealed fascinating patterns: large swirling currents form on the day side, similar to Earth's ocean gyres, and the deepest lava pools aren't directly under the star but at middle latitudes. Most intriguingly, the western edges of these lava oceans show much stronger currents than the eastern edges, creating a lopsided flow pattern.

**Looking Forward**

These findings provide the first realistic picture of circulation patterns on some of the most extreme planets we've discovered. As space telescopes like the James Webb Space Telescope study the atmospheres of distant worlds, understanding lava ocean dynamics will help interpret observations and identify these remarkable planets among the thousands of exoplanets we're discovering.

papers.title: Helium escape in context: Comparative signatures of four close-in exoplanets
papers.abstract: Observations of escaping atmospheres on close-in exoplanets show a wide range in the strength and morphology of He I 10830 A and H I absorption. Scaling relations attempt to link the He I signal to XUV irradiation, mass loss, and bulk planetary parameters. We test these relations with a comparative analysis of HD209458b, HD189733b, HD149026b, and GJ1214b using a 1D hydrodynamic, multi-species, full-atmosphere escape model. For the benchmark HD209458b, our previously validated solution reproduces the observed He I and Ha transit depths without imposing composition constraints. HD189733b exhibits comparable He I depths, but the broadest reported profiles require 12 km/s of additional non-thermal broadening, whereas more recent measurements are narrower, consistent with our predictions. For HD149026b, despite similar system properties, our model shows that higher gravity suppresses escape and enhances diffusive separation, depleting helium at high altitudes and yielding extremely weak He I absorption. For the sub-Neptune GJ1214b, H/He-only models overestimate He I absorption; including H2 and its ions (H2+, H3+, HeH+) lowers the escape rate and modifies the ion/electron balance, reducing the metastable helium densities. Compared against scaling relations, HD189733b observations and our HD149026b prediction fall below the trend, whereas some observations of HD209458b and GJ1214b are consistent; however, the observed transit depths are variable. Across all targets, we find diffusive separation of helium and hydrogen, which may explain why sub-solar He/H ratios are often required in simplified models. We conclude that interpreting He I and Ha absorption requires first-principles models that include self-consistent temperature and velocity profiles, multi-species transport, and molecular chemistry.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine you could watch alien worlds slowly losing their atmospheres to space, like steam rising from a hot cup of coffee. That's essentially what astronomers are doing when they study atmospheric escape from exoplanets‚Äîdistant worlds orbiting other stars. When planets orbit extremely close to their host stars, the intense radiation can strip away their atmospheres over millions of years. Understanding this process helps us learn how planets evolve, why some become barren rocks while others retain thick, protective atmospheres, and ultimately what makes worlds potentially habitable. This research is like having a cosmic laboratory to study planetary atmospheres under extreme conditions we could never replicate on Earth.

**What They Did**

The researchers focused on helium gas escaping from four different exoplanets that orbit very close to their stars. Using telescopes, astronomers can detect this escaping helium by observing how it absorbs specific wavelengths of starlight as the planet passes in front of its star‚Äîlike seeing a shadow with a chemical signature. The team built sophisticated computer models that simulate the entire atmospheric escape process, tracking how different gases behave under intense stellar radiation. Think of it as creating a detailed weather forecast, but for alien atmospheres being blasted by radiation. They then compared their predictions with actual telescope observations to test whether existing rules of thumb for predicting atmospheric escape actually work.

**Key Findings**

The results revealed that atmospheric escape is far more complex than scientists previously thought. Each planet showed unique behavior: one planet matched predictions perfectly, another showed unexpectedly broad absorption signatures requiring additional factors, a third planet (despite being similar to others) barely lost any helium due to its stronger gravity, and the fourth planet's escape was dramatically reduced when the model included hydrogen molecules. Surprisingly, the simple scaling relationships that astronomers often use to predict atmospheric loss failed for most planets. The researchers also discovered that helium and hydrogen separate during escape, like oil and water, which explains why previous studies often had to assume unrealistic atmospheric compositions.

**Looking Forward**

This work fundamentally changes how scientists approach exoplanet atmosphere studies. Rather than relying on simplified rules, researchers now realize they need comprehensive models that account for complex chemistry and physics. This could revolutionize our understanding of how planets lose their atmospheres and help us better predict which distant worlds might retain the protective atmospheric blankets necessary for life.

papers.title: Chasing the Tides: Searching for Orbital Decay Signatures in Transit Timing Data and Tidal Models for 20 Hot Jupiters
papers.abstract: In this work, we present a transit timing variation analysis for 20 hot Jupiter systems, which we interpret with theoretical tidal dissipation models. For the majority of the sample, we conclude that a constant orbital period model represents the timing data best. Only WASP-12 b, TrES-1 b and WASP-121 b exhibit a changing orbital period, according to the most up-to-date results. We updated the orbital decay rate of WASP-12 b to P = -29.4 ¬± 4.0 ms yr‚Åª¬π and the corresponding stellar tidal quality factor to Q‚àó‚Ä≤ = 1.72 ¬± 0.18 √ó 10‚Åµ. For TrES-1 b, the median quadratic model suggests a period decrease at a rate of -14.9 ¬± 0.6 ms yr‚Åª¬π, but the corresponding Q‚àó‚Ä≤ = 570 ¬± 60 does not agree with the theoretical estimates, which suggest Q‚àó‚Ä≤ 10‚Å∂ due to internal gravity wave dissipation. Lastly, WASP-121 b exhibits orbital growth at a rate of 15.1 ¬± 0.8 ms yr‚Åª¬π, and theoretical results support outward migration due to strong inertial wave dissipation.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine planets locked in a cosmic dance, slowly spiraling toward their stars like water circling a drain‚Äîor sometimes, surprisingly, moving away. This research tackles one of astronomy's most dramatic questions: what happens when massive planets orbit dangerously close to their host stars? These "hot Jupiters"‚Äîgas giants that whip around their stars in just days rather than years‚Äîexperience gravitational forces so intense they can literally stretch and squeeze both the planet and star. Understanding whether these worlds are doomed to crash into their stars or might escape to safer distances helps us grasp how planetary systems evolve and what fate awaits these alien worlds.

**What They Did**

The researchers acted like cosmic detectives, studying 20 hot Jupiter systems by carefully timing when each planet passed in front of its star‚Äîevents called transits. Think of it like watching a train schedule: if a train consistently arrives a few seconds earlier each day, something is changing about its journey. By measuring tiny shifts in transit timing over years of observations, scientists can detect whether a planet's orbit is shrinking or growing. They then compared these observations with theoretical models that predict how gravitational tides between stars and planets should behave, similar to how Earth's moon creates ocean tides but far more extreme.

**Key Findings**

Out of 20 planetary systems studied, only three showed clear signs of changing orbits. WASP-12 b is spiraling inward, with its year shrinking by about 29 milliseconds annually‚Äîmeaning it's on a collision course with its star. TrES-1 b also appears to be falling inward at roughly half that rate. Most surprisingly, WASP-121 b is actually moving away from its star, gaining about 15 milliseconds per year in its orbital period. The other 17 planets showed stable, unchanging orbits.

**Looking Forward**

These discoveries reveal that planetary fate isn't uniform‚Äîsome hot Jupiters face stellar doom while others might escape. This research provides crucial data for understanding planetary system evolution and helps astronomers predict which of these extreme worlds might survive long enough for future telescopes to study their atmospheres and composition.

Why It Matters

Imagine planets locked in a cosmic dance, slowly spiraling toward their stars like water circling a drain‚Äîor sometimes, surprisingly, moving away. This research tackles one of astronomy's most dramatic questions: what happens when massive planets orbit dangerously close to their host stars? These "hot Jupiters"‚Äîgas giants that whip around their stars in just days rather than years‚Äîexperience gravitational forces so intense they can literally stretch and squeeze both the planet and star. Understanding whether these worlds are doomed to crash into their stars or might escape to safer distances helps us grasp how planetary systems evolve and what fate awaits these alien worlds.

What They Did

The researchers acted like cosmic detectives, studying 20 hot Jupiter systems by carefully timing when each planet passed in front of its star‚Äîevents called transits. Think of it like watching a train schedule: if a train consistently arrives a few seconds earlier each day, something is changing about its journey. By measuring tiny shifts in transit timing over years of observations, scientists can detect whether a planet's orbit is shrinking or growing. They then compared these observations with theoretical models that predict how gravitational tides between stars and planets should behave, similar to how Earth's moon creates ocean tides but far more extreme.

Key Findings

Out of 20 planetary systems studied, only three showed clear signs of changing orbits. WASP-12 b is spiraling inward, with its year shrinking by about 29 milliseconds annually‚Äîmeaning it's on a collision course with its star. TrES-1 b also appears to be falling inward at roughly half that rate. Most surprisingly, WASP-121 b is actually moving away from its star, gaining about 15 milliseconds per year in its orbital period. The other 17 planets showed stable, unchanging orbits.

Looking Forward

These discoveries reveal that planetary fate isn't uniform‚Äîsome hot Jupiters face stellar doom while others might escape. This research provides crucial data for understanding planetary system evolution and helps astronomers predict which of these extreme worlds might survive long enough for future telescopes to study their atmospheres and composition.

papers.title: Modeling the Dynamics and Thermochemistry for the Outer Atmospheres of the Ultra-hot Jupiter WASP-121b
papers.abstract: We present three-dimensional simulations of the ultra-hot Jupiter (UHJ) WASP-121b from the planetary surface to extended outflows, coupling hydrodynamics with consistent non-equilibrium thermochemistry, ray-tracing radiative transfer, and hydrodynamics using the GPU-accelerated Kratos framework. The fiducial model exhibits several atmospheric layers, including the lower atmospheres controlled by day-night circulation, and transonic photoevaporative outflows at higher altitudes shaped into two spiral arms by the stellar gravity and orbital motion effects. Different species could trace different regions: Fe probes rotation-dominated inner layers, Na maps dense spiral arms where recombination balances photoionization, and HŒ± and He 10830 A features trace progressively more extended, ionized gas. With spiral arm velocities reaching 40 km\ s‚Åª¬π projected along the line of sight, this morphology explains observed high-velocity Na and HŒ± absorption features without requiring significant super-rotation jet streams. Parametric studies reveal complex dependencies on stellar irradiation: enhanced FUV intensifies outflows and extends spiral arms spatially and kinematically, while EUV and X-ray expands spiral structures into attenuated, ionized regions. Stellar wind confinement compresses the dayside outflow and enhances metastable helium absorption. This work demonstrates that current and future transmission spectral observations that probe multiple species can provide important constraints on astrophysical environments of UHJs by comparing state-of-the-art simulations.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine a planet so hot that its atmosphere is literally boiling away into space, creating dramatic spiral arms of gas stretching thousands of miles beyond the planet itself. That's WASP-121b, an "ultra-hot Jupiter" located 850 light-years from Earth. This alien world experiences temperatures hot enough to vaporize metals, making it one of the most extreme planets we know. Understanding how such planets lose their atmospheres helps us grasp the incredible diversity of worlds beyond our solar system and reveals the violent processes that shape planetary evolution throughout the universe.

**What They Did**

Scientists created the most detailed computer simulation ever made of WASP-121b's atmosphere, like building a virtual planet in a digital laboratory. Their model tracked how gases flow from the planet's surface all the way out to space, accounting for the scorching heat from the nearby star, chemical reactions happening in the atmosphere, and the gravitational dance between planet and star. Think of it as creating a weather forecast for an entire planet‚Äîbut instead of predicting rain or sunshine, they're tracking how different elements like iron, sodium, and helium behave as the atmosphere streams away into the void.

**Key Findings**

The simulation revealed that WASP-121b's escaping atmosphere forms two massive spiral arms, like a cosmic pinwheel spinning through space. These spirals reach speeds of 40 kilometers per second‚Äîfast enough to circle Earth in just over an hour. Different elements tell different parts of the story: iron stays closer to the planet in the rotating inner atmosphere, sodium traces the dense spiral structures, and hydrogen extends furthest out into space. This spiral structure explains mysterious high-speed signals that astronomers have detected when observing the planet.

**Looking Forward**

This breakthrough shows that we can now predict what escaping atmospheres should look like and match those predictions with telescope observations. As new space telescopes come online, scientists will be able to use these detailed models to study dozens of similar worlds, revealing how planets live, die, and transform in the most extreme corners of our galaxy.

papers.title: Detecting and Characterizing Companions with a Calibrated Gaia DR2, DR3, and Hipparcos Catalog (G23H)
papers.abstract: Gaia DR4 epoch astrometry will enable the detection of thousands of exoplanets through astrometric motion. Here, we present a composite catalog and modeling framework that extracts the maximum information from existing Hipparcos and Gaia data releases. We calibrate Gaia DR2 proper motions and DR3-DR2 scaled position differences against the Gaia DR3 reference frame, and combine these with the Hipparcos-Gaia Catalog of Accelerations, the Hipparcos intermediate astrometric data, Gaia astrometric excess noise, and Gaia radial velocity variability constraints. We implement a joint likelihood model for these data in Octofitter that marginalizes over Gaia's unpublished observation epochs. This results in full orbit posteriors that can be computed uniformly for a large class of companions. We compare these posteriors to published orbital solutions for 25 stellar binaries from the Sixth Catalog of Orbits of Visual Binary Stars, recovering all companions at high significance and broadly consistent orbital separations. We then recover independent evidence to support 94 of 120 tested Jovian exoplanetary systems from the NASA Exoplanet Archive (plus 3 known stellar companions, and one previously detected planet we now rule out). We demonstrate that in cases like 14 Her b, the posteriors confirm the planetary nature of a signal using only Gaia and Hipparcos data. We find no false positives among 25 RV-quiet standard stars without significant Hipparcos-Gaia accelerations. Our method can break degeneracies inherent to proper motion anomaly or excess noise modeling alone by resolving orbital curvature within the Gaia baseline. The catalog and updated Octofitter are made publicly available to the community.
papers.summary:
**Why It Matters**

Imagine trying to detect a firefly buzzing around a lighthouse from thousands of miles away‚Äîthat's essentially what astronomers face when hunting for planets orbiting distant stars. These "exoplanets" are incredibly difficult to spot directly, but they leave subtle clues in how their host stars move through space. This research represents a major breakthrough in our ability to find and study these alien worlds by combining decades of precise star-tracking data from space telescopes. Understanding how common planets are‚Äîand what kinds exist‚Äîhelps answer one of humanity's most profound questions: Are we alone in the universe?

**What They Did**

The researchers acted like cosmic detectives, combining clues from two major space missions that have been tracking star positions with incredible precision. The European Space Agency's Gaia telescope and its predecessor Hipparcos have been measuring tiny wobbles in starlight‚Äîmovements so small they're like detecting the width of a human hair from 25 miles away. When a planet orbits a star, both objects actually orbit around their shared center of gravity, causing the star to wobble slightly. By carefully analyzing these wobbles over decades, the team developed new mathematical tools to extract planetary signals from this treasure trove of data.

**Key Findings**

The results were remarkable: the researchers successfully confirmed 94 out of 120 known planetary systems using only this wobble data, essentially proving these worlds exist through an entirely independent method. They tested their approach on 25 binary star systems first‚Äîlike a practice round‚Äîand detected every single companion star with high confidence. Importantly, when they examined 25 "quiet" stars that shouldn't have planets, they found zero false alarms, proving their method is reliable.

**Looking Forward**

This research sets the stage for a golden age of planet discovery. When Gaia's next data release arrives, astronomers expect to find thousands of new worlds using these techniques. Unlike other planet-hunting methods that work best for specific types of planets, this approach can detect a wide variety of companions, potentially revealing entirely new categories of planetary systems in our galaxy.
